Trial_Design.evidence: A substudy of a randomised controlled trial.

Participants.evidence: One hundred and sixty-two patients with a BMI at least 35 kg per square metre undergoing elective open or laparoscopic surgery lasting at least 120 min.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised to PEEP of 4 cmH 2 O ( n = 79) or PEEP of 12 cmH 2 O with hourly ARMs ( n = 83).

Objective.evidence: To investigate the effects of PEEP levels and ARMs on ventilation distribution, oxygenation, haemodynamic parameters and cerebral oximetry.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint was the fraction of ventilation in the dependent lung as measured by electrical impedance tomography.

Number_Randomised.evidence: One hundred and sixty-two patients with a BMI at least 35 kg per square metre undergoing elective open or laparoscopic surgery lasting at least 120 min.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Patients were randomised to PEEP of 4 cmH 2 O ( n = 79) or PEEP of 12 cmH 2 O with hourly ARMs ( n = 83).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Compared with low PEEP, high PEEP was associated with smaller intra-operative decreases in dependent lung ventilation [-11.2%; 95% confidence interval (CI) -8.7 to -13.7 vs. -13.9%; 95% CI -11.7 to -16.5; P = 0.029], oxygen saturation index (-49.6%; 95% CI -48.0 to -51.3 vs. -51.3%; 95% CI -49.6 to -53.1; P < 0.001) and a lower driving pressure (-6.3 cmH 2 O; 95% CI -5.7 to -7.0).

Harms.evidence: Haemodynamic parameters did not differ between the groups, except at the end of ARMs when arterial pressure and cardiac index decreased on average by -13.7 mmHg (95% CI -12.5 to -14.9) and by -0.54 l min -1 m -2 (95% CI -0.49 to -0.59) along with increased cerebral tissue oximetry (3.0 and 3.2% on left and right front brain, respectively).
